text: A 5-year-old boy has had difficulty climbing stairs and getting up from the floor over the past 2 years. His parents noticed he uses his hands to push off his thighs to stand and has a waddling gait. His calves look enlarged. No fever, no recent infections.

A 7-year-old boy presents with progressive muscle weakness, trouble running, and frequent falls since early childhood. Parents report toe walking and difficulty lifting his head when lying down. Calf muscles are bulky.
A 6-year-old boy is brought in for trouble standing from a seated position and using furniture to pull himself up. His gait is waddling and he has difficulty climbing stairs.
Parents of an 8-year-old boy report that he was late to walk and now has progressive difficulty walking distances. He pushes on thighs to stand and often walks on toes.
A 9-year-old boy has progressive proximal muscle weakness, Gowers maneuver, and waddling gait.
School-age boy with falls, enlarged calves, and difficulty climbing stairs without railing.
A 4-year-old boy with delayed motor milestones, late walking, and waddling gait.
An 11-year-old boy with long-standing proximal muscle weakness now needs support to stand and has calf hypertrophy.
Child has progressive weakness, difficulty climbing stairs, and a waddling gait. Calf hypertrophy present.
